 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : anna armstrong <anna.armstrong@ntu.ac.uk>  
 Subject : Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* ocTEL CMALT [#octel-cmalt] (4 items) Group: ocTEL CMALT [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/groups/octel-cmalt/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/members/frenchdisko/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=4&access_key=6c6bf74679cec6a33890fdad43d9ba90] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Foctel-cmalt%2Fnotifications%2F] rachelhtan [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/members/rachelhtan/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] posted an update: at 5:39 am, May 5, 2014 

	I’m glad to read that those who register for CMALT has up to 6 months to submit their e-portfolio. I should be able to catch up on that after my summer course towards MEd Learning, Design, Technology. In the meantime, I’ll lurked in this group – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/activity/p/3760/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] rachelhtan [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/members/rachelhtan/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] posted an update: at 11:42 am, May 5, 2014 

	Hello, it’s good to have a list of CMALT holders, but could we have some samples of their final portfolio? I’d like to be fairly ready before registering GBP150/USD253. Perhaps I missed the link… https://www.alt.ac.uk/sites/alt.ac.uk/files/assets_editor_uploads/documents/Cmalt%20holders%20list_2013_0.pdf – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/activity/p/3856/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] Maren Deepwell [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/members/alt_admin/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] posted an update: at 1:15 pm, May 5, 2014 

	Hi all,
Here is a welcome post ahead of the regular blog posts starting this week, from one of our volunteers, Tom Franklin. From this week, posts will appear in the course blog at http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/category/course-information/ and will be included in the daily newsletter. 

	CMALT and ocTEL – a welcome 

	I have been following some of the discussions that have been happening this week, and really enjoying the quality of much of it and the level of engagement that so many of you are showing (and I hope that I am demonstrating too). One of the things that I have been thinking about is how this relates to undertaking a CMALT (Certified Membership of the Association for Learning Technology) portfolio, and I think that it demonstrates the types of thing that we are looking for in your portfolio. 

	When assessingportfolios we are looking for three things relating to each of the headings. These are description of what you have done, evidence that you did it and reflection on what you learnt from doing it. I want to focus on reflection here for two reasons. Firstly, candidates often have the greatest difficulty with reflection (that is we often have to ask applicants to do more reflection before we can accept the applications) and secondly the topic this week has been so general that it is harder to relate to most of the specific sections of the portfolio. 

	I have seen considerable levels of reflection in some of the postings where people have commented not just on what they have done (description), but also why it worked (or didn’t) what might have made it work better and what they learnt from doing it. This is exactly what we are looking for in portfolios, and is really helpful for other participants in ocTEL. While CP Scott may have said “”comment is free, but facts are sacred” it is often the comment that is more useful for other people. This, for instance, is why case studies are such a popular way of understanding the possibilities of learning technology (or anything else for that matter). While it may be true that facts are sacred and comment is free (though most facts are contested anyway, and much comment wouldn’t be worth paying for) it is when they are combined in a thoughtful way that the greatest understanding is developed both by the writer, and the reader. When you are writing posts, or reading posts (whether blogs or in the forum or anywhere else) think about what is description, what is the evidence supporting it and what reflection there is. Try to include some reflection in all your postings, it will really help to further your own understanding, and yes, I know I have not included reflection in all my postings, so I will try harder for the rest of ocTEL to include some reflection in my postings. 

	One of the other areas that we are looking for in CMALT portfolios is communications both as something to write about specifically in section 3 and because it relates to two of the principles behind CMALT: 

	· An empathy with and willingness to learn from colleagues from different backgrounds and specialisms. 

	· A commitment to communicate and disseminate effective practice. 

	Even vicarious learning supports the first of these two, whilst so many of you have been willing to comment on postings by others shows a commitment to communicate and disseminate effective practice. Indeed, particiaption in the MOOC could be used as evidence in the communications section. 

	The other two principles are: 

	· A commitment to exploring and understanding the interplay between technology and learning. 

	· A commitment to keep up to date with new technologies 

	And here again there has been the start of discussions in these areas, which I am sure you will be pursuing as the ocTEL continues through the other weeks on topics relating to learning and technology. 

	What is very clear to me is that many of you already have the knowledge and experience to gain CMALT recognition, and that you can use ocTEL both to increase your understanding of learning technology and learning and to reflect on what you already know and do. That makes an ideal preparation for completing your CMALT portfolio, so I hope to see a flood of submissions at the end of June or start of July. 

	Good luck and enjoy ocTEL.
Tom – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/activity/p/3888/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] Maren Deepwell [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/members/alt_admin/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 1:16 pm, May 5, 2014 

	Hi Rachel,
If you are looking for examples, there are some included in the Appendix to the guidelines for candidates at https://www.alt.ac.uk/sites/alt.ac.uk/files/assets_editor_uploads/documents/CMALT_Guidelines_2014.pdf
We are also sharing some example portfolios at http://cmalt-net.alt.ac.uk/pages/portfolios
Hope this helps,
Maren – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00/members/frenchdisko/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group. 

	 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

<div style="padding: 10px; border-top: 1px #eee solid;"><span style="color:#888;"><a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/rachelhtan/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00" title="rachelhtan">rachelhtan</a> posted an update: <span style="font-size:85%; color:#bbb; margin-left:8px;">at 5:39 am, May 5, 2014</span></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333;">I&#8217;m glad to read that those who register for CMALT has up to 6 months to submit their e-portfolio. I should be able to catch up on that after my summer course towards MEd Learning, Design, Technology. In the meantime, I&#8217;ll lurked in this group <img src="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_smile.gif" alt=":)" class="wp-smiley" /> </span> &#8211; <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3760/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00">View</a></div>
<div style="padding: 10px; border-top: 1px #eee solid;"><span style="color:#888;"><a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/rachelhtan/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00" title="rachelhtan">rachelhtan</a> posted an update: <span style="font-size:85%; color:#bbb; margin-left:8px;">at 11:42 am, May 5, 2014</span></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333;">Hello, it&#8217;s good to have a list of CMALT holders, but could we have some samples of their final portfolio? I&#8217;d like to be fairly ready before registering GBP150/USD253. Perhaps I missed the link&#8230;  https://www.alt.ac.uk/sites/alt.ac.uk/files/assets_editor_uploads/documents/Cmalt%20holders%20list_2013_0.pdf</span> &#8211; <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3856/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00">View</a></div>
<div style="padding: 10px; border-top: 1px #eee solid;"><span style="color:#888;"><a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/alt_admin/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00" title="Maren Deepwell">Maren Deepwell</a> posted an update: <span style="font-size:85%; color:#bbb; margin-left:8px;">at 1:15 pm, May 5, 2014</span></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333;">Hi all,<br />
Here is a welcome post ahead of the regular blog posts starting this week, from one of our volunteers, Tom Franklin. From this week, posts will appear in the course blog at http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/category/course-information/ and will be included in the daily newsletter. </p>
<p>CMALT and ocTEL &#8211; a welcome</p>
<p>I have been following some of the discussions that have been happening this week, and really enjoying the quality of much of it and the level of engagement that so many of you are showing (and I hope that I am demonstrating too).  One of the things that I have been thinking about is how this relates to undertaking a CMALT (Certified Membership of the Association for Learning Technology) portfolio, and I think that it demonstrates the types of thing that we are looking for in your portfolio. </p>
<p>When assessingportfolios we are looking for three things relating to each of the headings.  These are description of what you have done, evidence that you did it and reflection on what you learnt from doing it.  I want to focus on reflection here for two reasons.  Firstly, candidates often have the greatest difficulty with reflection (that is we often have to ask applicants to do more reflection before we can accept the applications) and secondly the topic this week has been so general that it is harder to relate to most of the specific sections of the portfolio.</p>
<p>I have seen considerable levels of reflection in some of the postings where people have commented not just on what they have done (description), but also why it worked (or didn’t) what might have made it work better and what they learnt from doing it.  This is exactly what we are looking for in portfolios, and is really helpful for other participants in ocTEL.  While CP Scott may have said “&#8221;comment is free, but facts are sacred” it is often the comment that is more useful for other people. This, for instance, is why case studies are such a popular way of understanding the possibilities of learning technology (or anything else for that matter).  While it may be true that facts are sacred and comment is free (though most facts are contested anyway, and much comment wouldn’t be worth paying for) it is when they are combined in a thoughtful way that the greatest understanding is developed both by the writer, and the reader.  When you are writing posts, or reading posts (whether blogs or in the forum or anywhere else) think about what is description, what is the evidence supporting it and what reflection there is.  Try to include some reflection in all your postings, it will really help to further your own understanding, and yes, I know I have not included reflection in all my postings, so I will try harder for the rest of ocTEL to include some reflection in my postings.</p>
<p>One of the other areas that we are looking for in CMALT portfolios is communications both as something to write about specifically in section 3 and because it relates to two of the principles behind CMALT:</p>
<p>·       An empathy with and willingness to learn from colleagues from different backgrounds and specialisms.</p>
<p>·       A commitment to communicate and disseminate effective practice.</p>
<p>Even vicarious learning supports the first of these two, whilst so many of you have been willing to comment on postings by others shows a commitment to communicate and disseminate effective practice.  Indeed, particiaption in the MOOC could be used as evidence in the communications section.</p>
<p>The other two principles are:</p>
<p>·       A commitment to exploring and understanding the interplay between technology and learning.</p>
<p>·       A commitment to keep up to date with new technologies</p>
<p>And here again there has been the start of discussions in these areas, which I am sure you will be pursuing as the ocTEL continues through the other weeks on topics relating to learning and technology.</p>
<p>What is very clear to me is that many of you already have the knowledge and experience to gain CMALT recognition, and that you can use ocTEL both to increase your understanding of learning technology and learning  and to reflect on what you already know and do.  That makes an ideal preparation for completing your CMALT portfolio, so I hope to see a flood of submissions at the end of June or start of July.</p>
<p>Good luck and enjoy ocTEL.<br />
Tom</span> &#8211; <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3888/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00">View</a></div>
<div style="padding: 10px; border-top: 1px #eee solid;"><span style="color:#888;"><a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/alt_admin/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00" title="Maren Deepwell">Maren Deepwell</a> posted a new activity comment: <span style="font-size:85%; color:#bbb; margin-left:8px;">at 1:16 pm, May 5, 2014</span></span></p>
<p><span style="color:#333;">Hi Rachel,<br />
If you are looking for examples, there are some included in the Appendix to the guidelines for candidates at https://www.alt.ac.uk/sites/alt.ac.uk/files/assets_editor_uploads/documents/CMALT_Guidelines_2014.pdf<br />
We are also sharing some example portfolios at http://cmalt-net.alt.ac.uk/pages/portfolios<br />
Hope this helps,<br />
Maren</span> &#8211; <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00">View</a></div>
<div class="ass-footer" style="margin:25px 0 0; padding-top:5px; border-top:1px #bbb solid;">You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014.</p>
<p>To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/frenchdisko/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__446&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:13+00:00">My Groups</a> where you can change your email settings for each group.</div>
<p></body></html></p>

	As a result of thinking that through, I’ve come up with one new initiative: I’m going to invite one of the Learning Designers to attend each of my department’s monthly departmental meetings. The LD will have a standing agenda item each month: s/he will either give an update about a piece of tech that is working particularly well in our areas at the moment, and/or take questions from academic staff about tech ideas they have. Could be a neat way to bridge the sometimes gap between techs and academics, a way to get us working together. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__448&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:17+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__448&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:17+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014.

it is completely open to all to edit and improve. I guess we will all have different contexts so it is about capturing all the challenges and opportunities as they are seen by the whole group. All welcome, sign in to the google doc if you have an account.
I look forward to some computer-mediated interaction – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] Julie Tardy [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/members/jtardy42/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 5:34 pm, May 5, 2014 

	Thanks Teresa, will think about that and complete, i hope, the doc with ”bright” ideas! – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] Alicia Vallero [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/members/alvaller/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 11:14 pm, May 5, 2014 

	I’m in too! Also from a different time zone (GMT+10). – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] Group: Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/members/alvaller/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=20&access_key=4da0bfbfcd56bbc2239558cbbed3c582] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fenthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel%2Fnotifications%2F] sal_chappell [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/members/sal_chappell/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 8:14 pm, May 5, 2014 

	Helen, I agree the monthly sessions are brilliant (and I’ve learnt loads!), but I still think we face the perennial problem of how we get new faces along to them. Having said that (see, arguing with myself now!), maybe we (I) should question whether that’s absolutely necessary. If the ”champions” are the ones coming to the sessions *and* they manage to disseminate info to departments, then maybe we don’t need to worry about getting more people to the monthly sessions. My concern, however, is that these ”champions” aren’t supported in this role, so the information enhances their practice but doesn’t reach a wider audience. I totally agree that case studies are really helpful – we definitely need more sharing of best practice with real-life examples – it makes it so much easier for people to see how they could use it in their teaching then. That’s why the champion system should work really well, as these individuals should be able to show relevant examples to their colleagues. Recognition schemes are a great incentive, and we do have some of those, which is a great start. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00/members/alvaller/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__449&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:19+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group.

	I’m glad to read that those who register for CMALT has up to 6 months to submit their e-portfolio. In the meantime, I’ll lurked in this group – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/activity/p/3760/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00] rachelhtan [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/members/rachelhtan/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00] posted an update: at 11:42 am, May 5, 2014 

	Hello, it’s good to have a list of CMALT holders, but could we have some samples of their final portfolio? I’d like to be fairly ready before registering GBP150/USD253. Perhaps I missed the link… https://www.alt.ac.uk/sites/alt.ac.uk/files/assets_editor_uploads/documents/Cmalt%20holders%20list_2013_0.pdf – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/activity/p/3856/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00] Maren Deepwell [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/members/alt_admin/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00] posted an update: at 1:15 pm, May 5, 2014 

	Hi all,
Here is a welcome post ahead of the regular blog posts starting this week, from one of our volunteers, Tom Franklin. From this week, posts will appear in the course blog at http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/category/course-information/ and will be included in the daily newsletter. 

	CMALT and ocTEL – a welcome 

	I have been following some of the discussions that have been happening this week, and really enjoying the quality of much of it and the level of engagement that so many of you are showing (and I hope that I am demonstrating too). One of the things that I have been thinking about is how this relates to undertaking a CMALT (Certified Membership of the Association for Learning Technology) portfolio, and I think that it demonstrates the types of thing that we are looking for in your portfolio. 

	When assessingportfolios we are looking for three things relating to each of the headings. These are description of what you have done, evidence that you did it and reflection on what you learnt from doing it. I want to focus on reflection here for two reasons. Firstly, candidates often have the greatest difficulty with reflection (that is we often have to ask applicants to do more reflection before we can accept the applications) and secondly the topic this week has been so general that it is harder to relate to most of the specific sections of the portfolio. 

	I have seen considerable levels of reflection in some of the postings where people have commented not just on what they have done (description), but also why it worked (or didn’t) what might have made it work better and what they learnt from doing it. This is exactly what we are looking for in portfolios, and is really helpful for other participants in ocTEL. While CP Scott may have said “”comment is free, but facts are sacred” it is often the comment that is more useful for other people. This, for instance, is why case studies are such a popular way of understanding the possibilities of learning technology (or anything else for that matter). While it may be true that facts are sacred and comment is free (though most facts are contested anyway, and much comment wouldn’t be worth paying for) it is when they are combined in a thoughtful way that the greatest understanding is developed both by the writer, and the reader. When you are writing posts, or reading posts (whether blogs or in the forum or anywhere else) think about what is description, what is the evidence supporting it and what reflection there is. Try to include some reflection in all your postings, it will really help to further your own understanding, and yes, I know I have not included reflection in all my postings, so I will try harder for the rest of ocTEL to include some reflection in my postings. 

	One of the other areas that we are looking for in CMALT portfolios is communications both as something to write about specifically in section 3 and because it relates to two of the principles behind CMALT: 

	· An empathy with and willingness to learn from colleagues from different backgrounds and specialisms. 

	· A commitment to communicate and disseminate effective practice. 

	Even vicarious learning supports the first of these two, whilst so many of you have been willing to comment on postings by others shows a commitment to communicate and disseminate effective practice. Indeed, particiaption in the MOOC could be used as evidence in the communications section. 

	The other two principles are: 

	· A commitment to exploring and understanding the interplay between technology and learning. 

	· A commitment to keep up to date with new technologies 

	And here again there has been the start of discussions in these areas, which I am sure you will be pursuing as the ocTEL continues through the other weeks on topics relating to learning and technology. 

	What is very clear to me is that many of you already have the knowledge and experience to gain CMALT recognition, and that you can use ocTEL both to increase your understanding of learning technology and learning and to reflect on what you already know and do. That makes an ideal preparation for completing your CMALT portfolio, so I hope to see a flood of submissions at the end of June or start of July. 

	Good luck and enjoy ocTEL.
Tom – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/activity/p/3888/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00] Maren Deepwell [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/members/alt_admin/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 1:16 pm, May 5, 2014 

	Hi Rachel,
If you are looking for examples, there are some included in the Appendix to the guidelines for candidates at https://www.alt.ac.uk/sites/alt.ac.uk/files/assets_editor_uploads/documents/CMALT_Guidelines_2014.pdf
We are also sharing some example portfolios at http://cmalt-net.alt.ac.uk/pages/portfolios
Hope this helps,
Maren – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00/members/mattsmeeth/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group.

<p><span style="color:#333;">Hi all,<br />
Here is a welcome post ahead of the regular blog posts starting this week, from one of our volunteers, Tom Franklin. From this week, posts will appear in the course blog at http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/category/course-information/ and will be included in the daily newsletter. </p>
<p>CMALT and ocTEL &#8211; a welcome</p>
<p>I have been following some of the discussions that have been happening this week, and really enjoying the quality of much of it and the level of engagement that so many of you are showing (and I hope that I am demonstrating too).  One of the things that I have been thinking about is how this relates to undertaking a CMALT (Certified Membership of the Association for Learning Technology) portfolio, and I think that it demonstrates the types of thing that we are looking for in your portfolio. </p>
<p>When assessingportfolios we are looking for three things relating to each of the headings.  These are description of what you have done, evidence that you did it and reflection on what you learnt from doing it.  I want to focus on reflection here for two reasons.  Firstly, candidates often have the greatest difficulty with reflection (that is we often have to ask applicants to do more reflection before we can accept the applications) and secondly the topic this week has been so general that it is harder to relate to most of the specific sections of the portfolio.</p>
<p>I have seen considerable levels of reflection in some of the postings where people have commented not just on what they have done (description), but also why it worked (or didn’t) what might have made it work better and what they learnt from doing it.  This is exactly what we are looking for in portfolios, and is really helpful for other participants in ocTEL.  While CP Scott may have said “&#8221;comment is free, but facts are sacred” it is often the comment that is more useful for other people. This, for instance, is why case studies are such a popular way of understanding the possibilities of learning technology (or anything else for that matter).  While it may be true that facts are sacred and comment is free (though most facts are contested anyway, and much comment wouldn’t be worth paying for) it is when they are combined in a thoughtful way that the greatest understanding is developed both by the writer, and the reader.  When you are writing posts, or reading posts (whether blogs or in the forum or anywhere else) think about what is description, what is the evidence supporting it and what reflection there is.  Try to include some reflection in all your postings, it will really help to further your own understanding, and yes, I know I have not included reflection in all my postings, so I will try harder for the rest of ocTEL to include some reflection in my postings.</p>
<p>One of the other areas that we are looking for in CMALT portfolios is communications both as something to write about specifically in section 3 and because it relates to two of the principles behind CMALT:</p>
<p>·       An empathy with and willingness to learn from colleagues from different backgrounds and specialisms.</p>
<p>·       A commitment to communicate and disseminate effective practice.</p>
<p>Even vicarious learning supports the first of these two, whilst so many of you have been willing to comment on postings by others shows a commitment to communicate and disseminate effective practice.  Indeed, particiaption in the MOOC could be used as evidence in the communications section.</p>
<p>The other two principles are:</p>
<p>·       A commitment to exploring and understanding the interplay between technology and learning.</p>
<p>·       A commitment to keep up to date with new technologies</p>
<p>And here again there has been the start of discussions in these areas, which I am sure you will be pursuing as the ocTEL continues through the other weeks on topics relating to learning and technology.</p>
<p>What is very clear to me is that many of you already have the knowledge and experience to gain CMALT recognition, and that you can use ocTEL both to increase your understanding of learning technology and learning  and to reflect on what you already know and do.  That makes an ideal preparation for completing your CMALT portfolio, so I hope to see a flood of submissions at the end of June or start of July.</p>
<p>Good luck and enjoy ocTEL.<br />
Tom</span> &#8211; <a href="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3888/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__450&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:21+00:00">View</a></div>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [#enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel] (1 items) Group: Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00/members/romieh/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=20&access_key=32c5edce22bb4c65914b70ff4ef7bec0] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fenthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel%2Fnotifications%2F] sal_chappell [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00/members/sal_chappell/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 8:14 pm, May 5, 2014 

	Helen, I agree the monthly sessions are brilliant (and I’ve learnt loads!), but I still think we face the perennial problem of how we get new faces along to them. Having said that (see, arguing with myself now!), maybe we (I) should question whether that’s absolutely necessary. If the ”champions” are the ones coming to the sessions *and* they manage to disseminate info to departments, then maybe we don’t need to worry about getting more people to the monthly sessions. My concern, however, is that these ”champions” aren’t supported in this role, so the information enhances their practice but doesn’t reach a wider audience. I totally agree that case studies are really helpful – we definitely need more sharing of best practice with real-life examples – it makes it so much easier for people to see how they could use it in their teaching then. That’s why the champion system should work really well, as these individuals should be able to show relevant examples to their colleagues. Recognition schemes are a great incentive, and we do have some of those, which is a great start. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00/members/romieh/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__451&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:23+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group.

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : m s anderson <m.s.anderson@greenwich.ac.uk>  
 Subject : Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Your daily digest of group activity [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	 Your daily digest of group activity at ocTEL 2014 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00] Group Summary: 
	* Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [#enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel] (1 items) Group: Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00] To disable these notifications for this group click unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00/members/m_anderson_phd/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=20&access_key=01564c405204ea56cc4ed06cdf47226b] – change email options [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fenthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel%2Fnotifications%2F] sal_chappell [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00/members/sal_chappell/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00] posted a new activity comment: at 8:14 pm, May 5, 2014 

	Helen, I agree the monthly sessions are brilliant (and I’ve learnt loads!), but I still think we face the perennial problem of how we get new faces along to them. Having said that (see, arguing with myself now!), maybe we (I) should question whether that’s absolutely necessary. If the ”champions” are the ones coming to the sessions *and* they manage to disseminate info to departments, then maybe we don’t need to worry about getting more people to the monthly sessions. My concern, however, is that these ”champions” aren’t supported in this role, so the information enhances their practice but doesn’t reach a wider audience. I totally agree that case studies are really helpful – we definitely need more sharing of best practice with real-life examples – it makes it so much easier for people to see how they could use it in their teaching then. That’s why the champion system should work really well, as these individuals should be able to show relevant examples to their colleagues. Recognition schemes are a great incentive, and we do have some of those, which is a great start. – View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00/activity/p//?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00] You have received this message because you are subscribed to receive a digest of activity in some of your groups on ocTEL 2014. 

	To disable these notifications per group please login and go to: My Groups [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00/members/m_anderson_phd/groups/?utm_source=mailpress&utm_medium=email_link&utm_content=__452&utm_campaign=2014-05-06T05:00:24+00:00] where you can change your email settings for each group. 

	 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=1e2b3e0b11972c08303f10dd4d53db56&id=452]

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : vearg <vearg@manchesterfire.gov.uk>  
 Subject : Gary Vear posted a new activity comment in the group Art & Design [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Gary Vear posted a new activity comment in the group Art & Design [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	Gary Vear posted a new activity comment in the group Art & Design 

	“During my time there they ethos from Senior Management was very anti -Social media (in fact, I remember attending a compulsory e-Safety CPD session which was the worst case of scare mongering I have witnessed. “If a child has facebook, they will meet a paedophile and bad things happen” was the message being deliver 

	During my final six months there they did make the jump to run an institutional twitter to aid marketing etc. However, they also introduced a college policy that staff could not use their own twitter feed/blog to promote their courses or celebrate their learners work. College reputation and all that. 

	Ideally , they wanted everyone to interact via the Moodle, however it was poorly designed with a very corporate feel and learners struggled to engage with it.” 

	To view or reply, log in and go to: 

	http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/art-design/ 

	———————
Your email setting for this group is: All Email
To change your email setting for this group, please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fart-design%2Fnotifications%2F 

	To disable all notifications for this group, click: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/vearg/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=16&access_key=a028976757258c62d9d8aef593cb390b 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=b7b37477c02e3f5a1a960ee1040dd99e&id=455]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=b7b37477c02e3f5a1a960ee1040dd99e]

 <p>Gary Vear posted a new activity comment in the group Art &amp; Design</p>
<p>&#8220;During my time there they ethos from Senior Management was very anti -Social media (in fact, I remember attending a compulsory e-Safety CPD session which was the worst case of scare mongering I have witnessed. &#8220;If a child has facebook, they will meet a paedophile and bad things happen&#8221; was the message being deliver</p>
<p>During my final six months there they did make the jump to run an institutional twitter to aid marketing etc. However, they also introduced a college policy that staff could not use their own  twitter feed/blog to promote their courses or celebrate their learners work. College reputation and all that.</p>
<p>Ideally , they wanted everyone to interact via the Moodle, however it was poorly designed with a very corporate feel and learners struggled to engage with it.&#8221;</p>
<p>To view or reply, log in and go to:</p>
<p>http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/art-design/</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Gary Vear replied to one of your updates 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Gary Vear replied to one of your updates !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	Gary Vear replied to one of your updates: 

	“During my time there they ethos from Senior Management was very anti -Social media (in fact, I remember attending a compulsory e-Safety CPD session which was the worst case of scare mongering I have witnessed. “If a child has facebook, they will meet a paedophile and bad things happen” was the message being deliver 

	During my final six months there they did make the jump to run an institutional twitter to aid marketing etc. However, they also introduced a college policy that staff could not use their own twitter feed/blog to promote their courses or celebrate their learners work. College reputation and all that. 

	Ideally , they wanted everyone to interact via the Moodle, however it was poorly designed with a very corporate feel and learners struggled to engage with it.” 

	To view your original update and all comments, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3309/ 

	———————
To disable these notifications please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/fleapalmer/settings/notifications/

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Gary Vear replied to one of your updates:</p>
<p>&#8220;During my time there they ethos from Senior Management was very anti -Social media (in fact, I remember attending a compulsory e-Safety CPD session which was the worst case of scare mongering I have witnessed. &#8220;If a child has facebook, they will meet a paedophile and bad things happen&#8221; was the message being deliver</p>
<p>During my final six months there they did make the jump to run an institutional twitter to aid marketing etc. However, they also introduced a college policy that staff could not use their own  twitter feed/blog to promote their courses or celebrate their learners work. College reputation and all that.</p>
<p>Ideally , they wanted everyone to interact via the Moodle, however it was poorly designed with a very corporate feel and learners struggled to engage with it.&#8221;</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : vearg <vearg@manchesterfire.gov.uk>  
 Subject : sue.bebbington posted an update in the group Art & Design [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! sue.bebbington posted an update in the group Art & Design [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	sue.bebbington posted an update in the group Art & Design 

	“I am an Education Technologist for the College of Arts and Social Sciences at the Australian National University. We have a diverse range of courses, including music, languages, philosophy, archaeology, arts and more, which all have some learning management system (moodle) presence. 

	I find that the level of technology use depends greatly on the lecturer concerned. Most moodle sites just have static information which could be text or health and safety videos, but as the lecturer gains confidence in using technology with their subject matter they begin looking for other ways to get technology to help them in some way. 

	My preferred practice is to find out what the lecturer needs help with, what they are trying to achieve, have they seen something similar, etc rather than saying ‘hey look at this, you must use it!’. If a pen and paper is the most sensible solution to a problem, then I will suggest it. 

	In my workplace my most important tool is patience, closely followed by compassion and the ability to listen.” 

	To view or reply, log in and go to: 

	http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/art-design/ 

	———————
Your email setting for this group is: All Email
To change your email setting for this group, please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fart-design%2Fnotifications%2F 

	To disable all notifications for this group, click: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/vearg/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=16&access_key=a028976757258c62d9d8aef593cb390b

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>sue.bebbington posted an update in the group Art &#038; Design</p>
<p>&#8220;I am an Education Technologist for the College of Arts and Social Sciences at the Australian National University. We have a diverse range of courses, including music, languages, philosophy, archaeology, arts and more, which all have some learning management system (moodle) presence. </p>
<p>I find that the level of technology use depends greatly on the lecturer concerned. Most moodle sites just have static information which could be text or health and safety videos, but as the lecturer gains confidence in using technology with their subject matter they begin looking for other ways to get technology to help them in some way. </p>
<p>My preferred practice is to find out what the lecturer needs help with, what they are trying to achieve, have they seen something similar, etc rather than saying &#8216;hey look at this, you must use it!&#8217;. If a pen and paper is the most sensible solution to a problem, then I will suggest it. </p>
<p>In my workplace my most important tool is patience, closely followed by compassion and the ability to listen.&#8221;</p>
<p>To view or reply, log in and go to:</p>
<p>http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/art-design/</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;<br />
Your email setting for this group is: All Email<br />

	Gary Vear posted a new activity comment in the group Art & Design 

	“Hi Sue 

	Personally I think that is a very good philosophy to have. Looking at needs rather than wants is the best approach, in my opinion, to enhancing learning. 

	I would be interested to discover how some of the more advanced lecturers use Tech to make their subject matters more interactive?”

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : vearg <vearg@manchesterfire.gov.uk>  
 Subject : Paul Rettey posted an update in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Paul Rettey posted an update in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	Paul Rettey posted an update in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection 

	“Hi Stuart, I know I responded on Twitter, but like most things I’ve reflected on my original view regards online behaviours. I’ve come to theory that online behaviours don’t change that much. 

	I’ll use myself as an example, as you can see I adopted one position to say that behaviours do change online, however I’ve since thought this statement through based on your questions on twitter. Deeper thinking and reflection has made me re-assess this view, it’s just that the use of social media / Web 2.0 technologies makes the behavior observable. So in a way by observing the data we find out the kinds of characters taking part online. 

	Again as you may have noticed, I like to get stuck in and help the setting up of the group, trying to spur the debate are all traits of my character. 

	In nutshell, I don’t think peoples behaviors change online as it’s a technological projection / representation of our persona’s.
“ 

	To view or reply, log in and go to: 

	http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection/ 

	———————
Your email setting for this group is: All Email
To change your email setting for this group, please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&auth=1&redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fpaul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection%2Fnotifications%2F 

	To disable all notifications for this group, click: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/vearg/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=2&access_key=0df36c711d1b8cd569a10427e82d2a8d 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=b7b37477c02e3f5a1a960ee1040dd99e&id=461]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=b7b37477c02e3f5a1a960ee1040dd99e] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Paul Rettey posted an update in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection</p>
<p>&#8220;Hi Stuart, I know I responded on Twitter, but like most things I&#8217;ve reflected on my original view regards online behaviours. I&#8217;ve come to theory that online behaviours don&#8217;t change that much.</p>
<p>I&#8217;ll use myself as an example, as you can see I adopted one position to say that behaviours do change online, however I&#8217;ve since thought this statement through based on your questions on twitter. Deeper thinking and reflection has made me re-assess this view, it&#8217;s just that the use of social media / Web 2.0 technologies makes the behavior observable. So in a way by observing the data we find out the kinds of characters taking part online.</p>
<p>Again as you may have noticed, I like to get stuck in and help the setting up of the group, trying to spur the debate are all traits of my character.</p>
<p>In nutshell, I don&#8217;t think peoples behaviors change online as it&#8217;s a technological projection / representation of our persona&#8217;s.<br />
&#8220;</p>
<p>To view or reply, log in and go to:</p>
<p>http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection/</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;<br />
Your email setting for this group is: All Email<br />
To change your email setting for this group, please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-login.php?action=bpnoaccess&#038;auth=1&#038;redirect_to=http%3A%2F%2Foctel.alt.ac.uk%2F2014%2Fgroups%2Fpaul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection%2Fnotifications%2F</p>

	Rose Heaney posted a new activity comment in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL 

	“I am certainly an advocate of the case study approach & we have made a modest start here blogs.uelconnect.org.uk/TEL/ with what we are calling ‘examples’. As a matter of interest, how would people define case study? We decided that it was much too glorified a term for what we have. “

	Rose Heaney replied to one of your updates: 

	“I am certainly an advocate of the case study approach & we have made a modest start here blogs.uelconnect.org.uk/TEL/ with what we are calling ‘examples’. As a matter of interest, how would people define case study? We decided that it was much too glorified a term for what we have. “

 <p>Rose Heaney replied to one of your updates:</p>
<p>&#8220;I am certainly an advocate of the case study approach &amp; we have made a modest start here blogs.uelconnect.org.uk/TEL/ with what we are calling &#8216;examples&#8217;. As a matter of interest, how would people define case study? We decided that it was much too glorified a term for what we have. &#8220;</p>

May 6, 2014



	Rose Heaney posted a new activity comment in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL 

	“I am certainly an advocate of the case study approach & we have made a modest start here http://blogs.uelconnect.org.uk/TEL/ with what we are calling ‘examples’. As a matter of interest, how would people define case study? We decided that it was much too glorified a term for what we have. “

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : john kelly <john.kelly@banbury-bicester.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=3a1d40e3e0febb5661007a028b2848ac&id=485]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=3a1d40e3e0febb5661007a028b2848ac] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>jesrinec wrote:</p>
<p>I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796</p>

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>jesrinec wrote:</p>

Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology.</p>

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796 

	———–

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology.

 <p>jesrinec wrote:</p>
<p>I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796</p>

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796 

	———–

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

	jesrinec wrote:

However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology.

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796

	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : cara saul <cara.saul@me.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	jesrinec wrote: 

	I agree, very interesting thread! As a Learning Technologist I have found students are much more accepting of TEL and that the biggest challenge lies in getting staff to engage with TEL. Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-10796 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

Like Bex I try to use plain English and analogy’s rather that technobabble to explain how technology works. However, I have found examples and case studies are also very useful in allowing people to focus on how the technology can be used to enhance their teaching and learning rather than how to use the technology itself. I tend to find much better buy-in if they can see its usefulness as a teaching tool, rather than a piece of technology.</p>
