 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : vearg <vearg@manchesterfire.gov.uk>  
 Subject : Paul Rettey posted a new activity comment in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! Paul Rettey posted a new activity comment in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	Paul Rettey posted a new activity comment in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection 

	“Hi, 

	I put this in my response to Big and Little questions but what you’ve said here is interesting 

	What’s the motivation for all stakeholders to use technology in learning? 

	This question should probe at why people want to implement, but also, why will people use it, and this more often than not causes differences in opinion. 

	My own view from looking at current practice is that it’s not common for systems to be properly joined up within Academia and this makes life very difficult for the users. Simply Learning Technologists are beholden to the IT department and the senior systems managers. 

	Strategically it makes better sense to design in all systems so that they are easy to use and involved less double handling of work.
Teachers are generally assessed against the success or failure of the students; and will not use a system that makes their lives more difficult. 

	To ‘win’ them over they need convincing that learning technology will make their lives easier. It cuts little ice with them when systems fail and they have to explain it to senior managers. So therefore it makes sense that they reduce the risk to them by avoiding its use where possible. Is there where the resistance is?, It’s catch 22. 

	To exacerbate the situation learning technologists and IT Departments sometimes don’t help. This is why it’s important to understand why people want to implement and look at the challenges involved not only technologically, but culturally.
“ 

	To view or reply, log in and go to: 

	http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection/ 

	———————
Your email setting for this group is: All Email

	To disable all notifications for this group, click: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/vearg/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=2&access_key=0df36c711d1b8cd569a10427e82d2a8d 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=b7b37477c02e3f5a1a960ee1040dd99e&id=511]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=b7b37477c02e3f5a1a960ee1040dd99e] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Paul Rettey posted a new activity comment in the group Paul is looking for participants: Activity 0.2: Small group reflection</p>
<p>&#8220;Hi,</p>
<p>I put this in my response to Big and Little questions but what you&#8217;ve said here is interesting</p>
<p>What’s the motivation for all stakeholders to use technology in learning?</p>
<p>This question should probe at why people want to implement, but also, why will people use it, and this more often than not causes differences in opinion.</p>
<p>My own view from looking at current practice is that it’s not common for systems to be properly joined up within Academia and this makes life very difficult for the users. Simply Learning Technologists are beholden to the IT department and the senior systems managers. </p>
<p>Strategically it makes better sense to design in all systems so that they are easy to use and involved less double handling of work.<br />
Teachers are generally assessed against the success or failure of the students; and will not use a system that makes their lives more difficult.</p>
<p>To ‘win’ them over they need convincing that learning technology will make their lives easier. It cuts little ice with them when systems fail and they have to explain it to senior managers. So therefore it makes sense that they reduce the risk to them by avoiding its use where possible. Is there where the resistance is?, It&#8217;s catch 22.</p>
<p>To exacerbate the situation learning technologists and IT Departments sometimes don’t help. This is why it’s important to understand why people want to implement and look at the challenges involved not only technologically, but culturally.<br />
&#8220;</p>
<p>To view or reply, log in and go to:</p>
<p>http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/paul-is-looking-for-participants-activity-0-2-small-group-reflection/</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Paul Rettey replied to one of your updates 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Paul Rettey replied to one of your updates !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	Paul Rettey replied to one of your updates: 

	“Hi, 

	I put this in my response to Big and Little questions but what you’ve said here is interesting 

	What’s the motivation for all stakeholders to use technology in learning? 

	This question should probe at why people want to implement, but also, why will people use it, and this more often than not causes differences in opinion. 

	My own view from looking at current practice is that it’s not common for systems to be properly joined up within Academia and this makes life very difficult for the users. Simply Learning Technologists are beholden to the IT department and the senior systems managers. 

	Strategically it makes better sense to design in all systems so that they are easy to use and involved less double handling of work.
Teachers are generally assessed against the success or failure of the students; and will not use a system that makes their lives more difficult. 

	To ‘win’ them over they need convincing that learning technology will make their lives easier. It cuts little ice with them when systems fail and they have to explain it to senior managers. So therefore it makes sense that they reduce the risk to them by avoiding its use where possible. Is there where the resistance is?, It’s catch 22. 

	To exacerbate the situation learning technologists and IT Departments sometimes don’t help. This is why it’s important to understand why people want to implement and look at the challenges involved not only technologically, but culturally.
“ 

	To view your original update and all comments, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3112/ 

	———————
To disable these notifications please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/gdoug/settings/notifications/ 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=a68b23c11b354ea49f12810f549a0699&id=512]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=a68b23c11b354ea49f12810f549a0699] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Paul Rettey replied to one of your updates:</p>
<p>&#8220;Hi,</p>
<p>I put this in my response to Big and Little questions but what you&#8217;ve said here is interesting</p>
<p>What’s the motivation for all stakeholders to use technology in learning?</p>
<p>This question should probe at why people want to implement, but also, why will people use it, and this more often than not causes differences in opinion.</p>
<p>My own view from looking at current practice is that it’s not common for systems to be properly joined up within Academia and this makes life very difficult for the users. Simply Learning Technologists are beholden to the IT department and the senior systems managers. </p>
<p>Strategically it makes better sense to design in all systems so that they are easy to use and involved less double handling of work.<br />
Teachers are generally assessed against the success or failure of the students; and will not use a system that makes their lives more difficult.</p>
<p>To ‘win’ them over they need convincing that learning technology will make their lives easier. It cuts little ice with them when systems fail and they have to explain it to senior managers. So therefore it makes sense that they reduce the risk to them by avoiding its use where possible. Is there where the resistance is?, It&#8217;s catch 22.</p>
<p>To exacerbate the situation learning technologists and IT Departments sometimes don’t help. This is why it’s important to understand why people want to implement and look at the challenges involved not only technologically, but culturally.<br />
&#8220;</p>
<p>To view your original update and all comments, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3112/</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;<br />
To disable these notifications please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/gdoug/settings/notifications/</p> 

 ------------------ end of mail ------------------

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : c collis <c.collis@qut.edu.au>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Paul Rettey replied to one of your comments 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Paul Rettey replied to one of your comments !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	Paul Rettey replied to one of your comments: 

	“Hi, 

	I put this in my response to Big and Little questions but what you’ve said here is interesting 

	What’s the motivation for all stakeholders to use technology in learning? 

	This question should probe at why people want to implement, but also, why will people use it, and this more often than not causes differences in opinion. 

	My own view from looking at current practice is that it’s not common for systems to be properly joined up within Academia and this makes life very difficult for the users. Simply Learning Technologists are beholden to the IT department and the senior systems managers. 

	Strategically it makes better sense to design in all systems so that they are easy to use and involved less double handling of work.
Teachers are generally assessed against the success or failure of the students; and will not use a system that makes their lives more difficult. 

	To ‘win’ them over they need convincing that learning technology will make their lives easier. It cuts little ice with them when systems fail and they have to explain it to senior managers. So therefore it makes sense that they reduce the risk to them by avoiding its use where possible. Is there where the resistance is?, It’s catch 22. 

	To exacerbate the situation learning technologists and IT Departments sometimes don’t help. This is why it’s important to understand why people want to implement and look at the challenges involved not only technologically, but culturally.
“ 

	To view the original activity, your comment and all replies, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3112/ 

	———————

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Paul Rettey replied to one of your comments:</p>
<p>&#8220;Hi,</p>
<p>I put this in my response to Big and Little questions but what you&#8217;ve said here is interesting</p>
<p>What’s the motivation for all stakeholders to use technology in learning?</p>
<p>This question should probe at why people want to implement, but also, why will people use it, and this more often than not causes differences in opinion.</p>
<p>My own view from looking at current practice is that it’s not common for systems to be properly joined up within Academia and this makes life very difficult for the users. Simply Learning Technologists are beholden to the IT department and the senior systems managers. </p>
<p>Strategically it makes better sense to design in all systems so that they are easy to use and involved less double handling of work.<br />
Teachers are generally assessed against the success or failure of the students; and will not use a system that makes their lives more difficult.</p>
<p>To ‘win’ them over they need convincing that learning technology will make their lives easier. It cuts little ice with them when systems fail and they have to explain it to senior managers. So therefore it makes sense that they reduce the risk to them by avoiding its use where possible. Is there where the resistance is?, It&#8217;s catch 22.</p>
<p>To exacerbate the situation learning technologists and IT Departments sometimes don’t help. This is why it’s important to understand why people want to implement and look at the challenges involved not only technologically, but culturally.<br />
&#8220;</p>
<p>To view the original activity, your comment and all replies, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/activity/p/3112/</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : jennifer schneider <jennifer.schneider@newcastle.edu.au>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Autonomous and social? 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Autonomous and social? !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	Gary Vear wrote: 

	I think it is becoming very difficult for learners to be autonomous. 

	This is my biggest grievance with the UK Education sector, thee is no correlation across levels. 

	Learners spend so much time in secondary education learning how to pass an exam. They have required information they must know about and GCSE’s have now become a glorified line learning exercise. 

	This is increasingly frustrating for those that teach in FE as by the time the learners get to us, they panic when given an autonomous task and really struggle to achieve. The truth of the matter is that they have the notion of independent thought bludgeoned out of them by the curriculum between 5-16 and they effectively are starting all over again when they go to college. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10804 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=feb19dd5f7f217642d987399d0b04d33&id=514]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=feb19dd5f7f217642d987399d0b04d33] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Gary Vear wrote:</p>
<p>I think it is becoming very difficult for learners to be autonomous.</p>
<p>This is my biggest grievance with the UK Education sector, thee is no correlation across levels.</p>
<p>Learners spend so much time in secondary education learning how to pass an exam. They have required information they must know about and GCSE&#8217;s have now become a glorified line learning exercise.</p>
<p>This is increasingly frustrating for those that teach in FE as by the time the learners get to us, they panic when given an autonomous task and really struggle to achieve. The truth of the matter is that they have the notion of independent thought bludgeoned out of them by the curriculum between 5-16 and they effectively are starting all over again when they go to college.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10804</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>
<p>You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic.</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : jennifer schneider <jennifer.schneider@newcastle.edu.au>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Autonomous and social? 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Autonomous and social? !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	philtubman wrote: 

	I think it might help to think of this in terms of a frame work like Blooms taxonomy or Maslows hierarchy of needs. 

	Social and autonomous learning almost always requires confidence in the subject matter, and in oneself (most importantly). It is about presenting your ideas within a group situation and finding your own way through the advice received, and consolidating it back into your own thinking (or your own ‘learning outcomes’)… 

	…so not best placed for an introductory task to the subject matter then 

	I think it would help to reflect on where these activity might sit on the Maslow hierarchy. I suspect we are looking right to the top of the triangle with most of these learning activities. 

	Also, with reference to Bloom, and to reply to Maren’s comment above about technology use, you might find this link useful as it details technologies and use cases at different points of the taxonomy. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/lv?key=0Ar0FfDINz1W_dGdwRTFUQlJYbGE0VWNXSUZCMWRjaVE&usp=sharing#gid=0 

	 

	Social and autonomous learning (and learning how to social and autonomous learn) is vital to studying at university, and the change of learning style is a well documented problem for undergraduates. It is however, a key life skill, and a precursor to digital fluency that will be required to navigate the changing work environment…. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10853 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=feb19dd5f7f217642d987399d0b04d33&id=523]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=feb19dd5f7f217642d987399d0b04d33] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>philtubman wrote:</p>
<p>I think it might help to think of this in terms of a frame work like Blooms taxonomy or Maslows hierarchy of needs.</p>
<p>Social and autonomous learning almost always requires confidence in the subject matter, and in oneself (most importantly). It is about presenting your ideas within a group situation and finding your own way through the advice received, and consolidating it back into your own thinking (or your own &#8216;learning outcomes&#8217;)&#8230;</p>
<p>&#8230;so not best placed for an introductory task to the subject matter then <img src="http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/wp-includes/images/smilies/icon_smile.gif" alt=":)" class="wp-smiley" /> </p>
<p>I think it would help to reflect on where these activity might sit on the Maslow hierarchy. I suspect we are looking right to the top of the triangle with most of these learning activities.</p>
<p>Also, with reference to Bloom, and to reply to Maren&#8217;s comment above about technology use, you might find this link useful as it details technologies and use cases at different points of the taxonomy. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheet/lv?key=0Ar0FfDINz1W_dGdwRTFUQlJYbGE0VWNXSUZCMWRjaVE&amp;usp=sharing#gid=0</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Social and autonomous learning (and learning how to social and autonomous learn) is vital to studying at university, and the change of learning style is a well documented problem for undergraduates. It is however, a key life skill, and a precursor to digital fluency that will be required to navigate the changing work environment&#8230;.</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/autonomous-and-social/#post-10853</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>
<p>You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic.</p>
<p>Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.</p> 

 ------------------ end of mail ------------------

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : vearg <vearg@manchesterfire.gov.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Individual and directed 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Individual and directed !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	philtubman wrote: 

	I think it is worth considering here that the task is related to the person as well as the learning objective. That is to say that different people will learn the same thing differently and prefer different styles of teaching. The point of this task for me is to critically examine what we are actually doing now, and work out if it is 

	a) the only way this can be taught
b) the best way of teaching for everyone 

	and then to consider 

	c) if doing it differently would help or harm or whether it would jeopardise other factors, such as time. 

	There is a great blog post here, which popped up on my G+ timeline last week: 

	http://www.hybridpedagogy.com/journal/online-learning/best-practices-thoughts-flash-mob-mentality/ 

	 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/individual-and-directed/#post-10906 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=b7b37477c02e3f5a1a960ee1040dd99e&id=540]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=b7b37477c02e3f5a1a960ee1040dd99e] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>philtubman wrote:</p>
<p>I think it is worth considering here that the task is related to the person as well as the learning objective. That is to say that different people will learn the same thing differently and prefer different styles of teaching. The point of this task for me is to critically examine what we are actually doing now, and work out if it is</p>
<p>a) the only way this can be taught<br />
b) the best way of teaching for everyone</p>
<p>and then to consider</p>
<p>c) if doing it differently would help or harm or whether it would jeopardise other factors, such as time.</p>
<p>There is a great blog post here, which popped up on my G+ timeline last week:</p>
<p>http://www.hybridpedagogy.com/journal/online-learning/best-practices-thoughts-flash-mob-mentality/</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/individual-and-directed/#post-10906</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : fleapalmer posted an update in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [ocTEL 2014] 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! fleapalmer posted an update in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL [ocTEL 2014] !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	fleapalmer posted an update in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL 

	“Wholeheartedly agree about the value of peer to peer TEL enthusing and have just been reading JISC InfKit: Supporting Staff -http://www.jiscinfonet.ac.uk/infokits/digital-literacies/practice/supporting-staff/ and ‘Online learning, faculty development and academic freedom’ – http://www.tonybates.ca/2014/05/05/online-learning-faculty-development-and-academic-freedom/ 

	Made me ponder… 

	Who runs TEL workshops? By that I mean is there collaboration between Learning Technologists, Educational Developers, Learning Developers, Librarians, IT staff, Careers Advisers, etc…? In reference to Tony’s second point, it’s got me wondering whether we could be a bit more ‘joined up’ in our delivery?..” 

	To view or reply, log in and go to: 

	http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/ 

	———————
Your email setting for this group is: All Email

	To disable all notifications for this group, click: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/citizendavis/?bpass-action=unsubscribe&group=20&access_key=e65f2d52414374b689ece541d095c04a

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>fleapalmer posted an update in the group Enthusing staff to engage with TEL</p>
<p>&#8220;Wholeheartedly agree about the value of peer to peer TEL enthusing and have just been reading JISC InfKit: Supporting Staff -http://www.jiscinfonet.ac.uk/infokits/digital-literacies/practice/supporting-staff/ and &#8216;Online learning, faculty development and academic freedom&#8217; &#8211; http://www.tonybates.ca/2014/05/05/online-learning-faculty-development-and-academic-freedom/ </p>
<p>Made me ponder&#8230;</p>
<p>Who runs TEL workshops? By that I mean is there collaboration between Learning Technologists, Educational Developers, Learning Developers, Librarians, IT staff, Careers Advisers, etc&#8230;? In reference to Tony&#8217;s second point, it&#8217;s got me wondering whether we could be a bit more &#8216;joined up&#8217; in our delivery?..&#8221;</p>
<p>To view or reply, log in and go to:</p>
<p>http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/groups/enthusing-staff-to-engage-with-tel/</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Gary Vear mentioned you in an update !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	Gary Vear mentioned you in an update: 

	“ @Philtubman [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/philtubman/] – thank you for the recommendation, I found that to be a very interesting read! 

	 @Andywilson48 [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/andywilson48/] – You really have pointed out the major flaw with the idea. How do we deem current practitioners to be of a good standard? Where do we find them? 

	I wouldn’t say all vocations are subjective. There is a definitive right way and wrong way to fix a car for example, but how is there a wrong way to paint a picture, this was the subjective assessment I was referring too. “ 

	To view and respond to the message, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/individual-and-directed/#post-10962 

	———————
To disable these notifications please log in and go to: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/philtubman/settings/notifications/ 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>Gary Vear mentioned you in an update:</p>
<p>&#8220;<a href='http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/philtubman/' rel='nofollow'>@Philtubman</a> &#8211; thank you for the recommendation, I found that to be a very interesting read!</p>
<p><a href='http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/members/andywilson48/' rel='nofollow'>@Andywilson48</a> &#8211; You really have pointed out the major flaw with the idea. How do we deem current practitioners to be of a good standard? Where do we find them?</p>
<p>I wouldn&#8217;t say all vocations are subjective. There is a definitive right way and wrong way to fix a car for example, but how is there a wrong way to paint a picture, this was the subjective assessment I was referring too. &#8220;</p>
<p>To view and respond to the message, log in and visit: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/individual-and-directed/#post-10962</p>

 ocTEL 2014

	Tom Franklin wrote: 

	It might be useful to think about ipsative assessment (as opposed to norm or criterion based assessment). In ipsative assessment the student is assessed against their prior learning and their desired learning. Of course, this can cause difficulties if you are trying to follow a curriculum for the whole cohort. 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/individual-and-directed/#post-10982 

	———–

	Elizabeth Charles wrote:

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : john kelly <john.kelly@banbury-bicester.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails. 

							this mail is brought to you by MailPress

View [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?view=3a1d40e3e0febb5661007a028b2848ac&id=560]
Unsubscribe [http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/newsletter-subscriptions/?del=3a1d40e3e0febb5661007a028b2848ac] 

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>
<p>You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic.</p>
<p>Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : glenn <glenn@learnpoint.co.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : david <david@ALCHEMI.CO.UK>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : tom <tom@franklin-consulting.co.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. 	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning.  From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : bali <bali@aucegypt.edu>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : hellycorke <hellycorke@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic.

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project.  ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : hellomrminiki <hellomrminiki@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : sue bebbington <sue.bebbington@anu.edu.au>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : mcjsa2 <mcjsa2@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.
