 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !

May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : kerr 63 <kerr.63@osu.edu>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>

However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible.  ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : web+mooc <web+mooc@mattstratford.org>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>
<p>You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic.</p>
<p>Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : belinda green <belinda.green@northampton.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>

 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : scott h t miller <scott.h.t.miller@gmail.com>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 ------------------- text/html -------------------  
 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&nbsp;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)&lt;/p&gt;</p>
<p>Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041</p>
<p>&#8212;&#8212;&#8212;&#8211;</p>

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : matt <matt@mattsmeeth.co.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>

 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041

 ------------------- start of mail -------------------   
 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : julie carrie <julie.carrie@uws.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———– 

	You are receiving this email because you subscribed to a forum topic. 

	Login and visit the topic to unsubscribe from these emails.

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />

	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p>

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : rosemary eaton <rosemary.eaton@southwales.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />

 From : ocTEL Newsletter <octel@alt.ac.uk>  
 To   : j clarke-darrington <j.clarke-darrington@shef.ac.uk>  
 Subject : [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions 
   ------------------- plaintext -------------------  
 ocTEL 2014
Open Course in Technology Enhanced Learning

* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
! [ocTEL 2014] Activity 0.1: Big and little questions !
* ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ *
May 6, 2014



	clarethomsonqub wrote: 

	<p class=”MsoNormal”>I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.</p>
<p class=”MsoNormal”>In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.</p>

<p class=”MsoNormal”>(I think I read over the week that there is an argument about removing the T from TEL in the same vein as removing the e from eLearning – note to me: find that post)</p> 

	Post Link: http://octel.alt.ac.uk/2014/forums/topic/activity-0-1-big-and-little-questions/#post-11041 

	———–

 <p>clarethomsonqub wrote:</p>
<p>&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;I have been skimming the posts in this large discussion over the last week and largely agree/empathise with them. However, just before I move onto week 1, my big question is “even though we have mostly moved towards the term ‘technology enhanced learning (TEL)’ will we ever be able to convince others that ‘elearning’ is no different to ‘learning’?”. My job title is elearning developer but I am continually frustrated that staff see what I do and advise doing regarding technology as separate entity to their learning and teaching. It is still face to face teaching versus materials delivered online, without a pedagogical connection between the two. Maybe my little question therefore is “should I get a new job title?”.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
&lt;p class=&#8221;MsoNormal&#8221;&gt;In medical education we have a large amount of online learning materials for the students which is in the main standalone and requires self direction on the part of the student. Everyone calls it blended learning. However, my manager and I disagree on the grounds that the teaching staff don’t make meaningful connections between the online material and their live content. We doubt that all the teachers even have a full knowledge of what is available online for their course and therefore don’t know what connections are possible. We are working on a pilot to get a truly blended course in one topic and hopefully turn this into a case study to try selling more TEL and less elearning. I think participating in MOOCs has assisted me lots in how we go about this project. To help deal with the barriers of content expert time constraints, lack of trust in technology, taking risks, selling it to co-teachers, lack of funds and resources etc.&lt;/p&gt;<br />
